clinical_study.brief_title: Impact of a High-fat Meal on Assessment of Clopidogrel-induced Platelet Inhibition in Healthy Subjects
clinical_study.official_title: Impact of a High-fat Meal on Assessment of Clopidogrel-induced Platelet Inhibition in Healthy Subjects

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to determine whether a high-fat meal affects the ability of platelet function tests to measure platelet inhibition by clopidogrel.

detailed_description.textblock: The purpose of this study is to determine the influence of a high-fat meal on assessment of clopidogrel-induced platelet inhibition in healthy people using platelet function assays. Twelve healthy adult subjects will be recruited to take part in this research study. After consent is obtained, subjects will be asked to present to the clinical research center after a 12 hour fast. A baseline blood sample will be drawn at 8 am, and subjects will then be administered a 600 mg dose of clopidogrel. At 12 noon, another blood sample will be drawn to evaluate the extent of maximum platelet inhibition in the fasting state. Subjects will then be provided a standardized high-fat meal with an additional blood sample at 2 pm to evaluate the impact of the high-fat on platelet function assessment.

primary_outcome.description: platelet inhibition before versus after a high-fat meal (measured by light transmission aggregometry, whole blood aggregometry, flow cytometry, and VerifyNow assay)

intervention.description: Clopidogrel 600 mg loading dose at 8 am and high-fat meal at 12 pm

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- 19 years of age or older
- healthy subjects
- deny taking medications that affect platelet function for at least 7 days prior to test
Exclusion Criteria:
- history of cardiovascular disease
- any risk factors for cardiovascular disease
- surgery in last 3 months
- history of anemia/thrombocytopenia
- pregnancy
